text:
Hi folks, I've been fiddling around with the projects spreadsheet here:

<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/12sTu7RT-s_QlAupY1v-3DfI1Mm9NEX5YMWWTDAKHLfc/edit?pli=1#gid=0>

and I thought I'd take this opportunity to ask you all to ensure your entries are complete and up-to-date.

New users welcome: just add your project! Note: your project should ideally be at least primarily open source.

elements.text: Hi folks, I've been fiddling around with the projects spreadsheet here:

and I thought I'd take this opportunity to ask you all to ensure your entries are complete and up-to-date.

New users welcome: just add your project! Note: your project should ideally be at least primarily open source.

text: .. or if commercial, please be technically interesting or different in some way, rather than filling the spreadsheet with marketing guff!

elements.text: .. or if commercial, please be technically interesting or different in some way, rather than filling the spreadsheet with marketing guff!

text: I've added a new row to allow people (like me!) to be able to claim they've created a new programming model paradigm.

elements.text: I've added a new row to allow people (like me!) to be able to claim they've created a new programming model paradigm.

text: Hey there <@UC2A2ARPT> , it seems like I should pass ownership of this over to you and the rest of The Management, what do you think? :hugging_face:

elements.text: Hey there
, it seems like I should pass ownership of this over to you and the rest of The Management, what do you think?

text:
I'd be happy to take it over, but be warned I will delete Dynamicland and its ilk from it if I do :smile: I might also deprioritize/archive many of the columns whose owners aren't active here anymore, since I see the sheet as a call for collaboration with people here.

(I'm stating my opinions strongly for contrast, but I'd be happy to be persuaded about individual decisions if people here feel strongly. But Dynamicland has got to go. There's no action there anyone can take, and it dilutes the sheet.)

elements.text: I'd be happy to take it over, but be warned I will delete Dynamicland and its ilk from it if I do

I might also deprioritize/archive many of the columns whose owners aren't active here anymore, since I see the sheet as a call for collaboration with people here.

(I'm stating my opinions strongly for contrast, but I'd be happy to be persuaded about individual decisions if people here feel strongly. But Dynamicland has got to go. There's no action there anyone can take, and it dilutes the sheet.)

text: Dynamicland is the only one I'd keep. Yours would be first for the axe! :joy:

elements.text: Dynamicland is the only one I'd keep. Yours would be first for the axe!

text: :joy:

Yeah, if you have a vision you gotta stick around for it. Nobody else will do it for you.

There is no exit.

elements.text:

text: I mean, arguably you should add a column for the Dynabook.

elements.text: I mean, arguably you should add a column for the Dynabook.

text: Seriously though, you chose the one project I would never want to see deleted, other than mine of course. Why the hating-on?

elements.text: Seriously though, you chose the one project I would never want to see deleted, other than mine of course. Why the hating-on?

text: Or are you joking?

elements.text: Or are you joking?

text:
Oh I love Dynamicland! How could I not?!

It has to do with what the goal for the sheet is. I've said this to you a few years ago. If you think the goal is to showcase the best work in the vein of this forum, Dynamicland and Dynabook make it in first.

But if the goal is to foster collaboration, they're dead weight.

Now if somebody were to try to recreate them, that would be top of the list again.

I wouldn't try to do both sides in a single sheet, that feels muddy to me.

elements.text:

It has to do with what the goal for the sheet is. I've said this to you a few years ago. If you think the goal is to showcase the best work in the vein of this forum, Dynamicland and Dynabook make it in first.

But if the goal is to foster collaboration, they're dead weight.

Now if somebody were to try to recreate them, that would be top of the list again.

I wouldn't try to do both sides in a single sheet, that feels muddy to me.

text: Original goal is to allow comparison and inspiration

elements.text: Original goal is to allow comparison and inspiration

text: Oh interesting! :thinking_face: That somehow was never clear to me until now.

elements.text: Oh interesting!
That somehow was never clear to me until now.

text:
Many of the rows don't make sense for Dynamicland. It shouldn't matter how many people work on it, or whether it's active or not.

I'll reiterate that you should add more from the past then. Dynabook, Boxer. Ivan's Visual Programming Codex has more projects like that.

Hmm, arguably the VPCodex does a great job already of comparison and inspiration.

text: Another axis to consider here is the audience. If you care about projects that are personally inspiring, that will vary from person to person. I'd make that a page on your website that you update and nobody else can. Pretty low-maintenance.

elements.text: Another axis to consider here is the audience. If you care about projects that are personally inspiring, that will vary from person to person. I'd make that a page on your website that you update and nobody else can. Pretty low-maintenance.

text: I'm really enjoying collaborating with dynamicland, and according to their current website, 2022 was earmarked for 'dynamicland meets the world'. Delayed somewhat, I guess mainly by the pandemic..

elements.text: I'm really enjoying collaborating with dynamicland, and according to their current website, 2022 was earmarked for 'dynamicland meets the world'. Delayed somewhat, I guess mainly by the pandemic..

text: Oh I'd love to hear more Alex. Perhaps share resources in a new thread? Sorry Duncan I've destroyed this thread.. :confused:

text: My perception is it's not taking input in the same way an online community is. There's a pretty fundamental impedance mismatch.

elements.text: My perception is it's not taking input in the same way an online community is. There's a pretty fundamental impedance mismatch.

text: Yes it's an outlier for sure.

elements.text: Yes it's an outlier for sure.

text: Absolutely legitimate trade-off to make. But there _are_ things they're trading off. And among them is being on "my" spreadsheet.

elements.text: Absolutely legitimate trade-off to make. But there
are
things they're trading off. And among them is being on "my" spreadsheet.

text: Personally I've got loads out of collaborating with Luke, although I am very much a free/open source person myself. I think the early stages of development of a creative idea is a special time that should be somewhat protected, and I guess they're in it for the long haul. I'm also sympathetic to the idea that open source techbro culture isn't a panacea, and their pre-pandemic focus on in-person collaboration and continued focus on long-haul in-the-community nonprofit development is really interesting.. plus their new website will share a _lot._

elements.text: Personally I've got loads out of collaborating with Luke, although I am very much a free/open source person myself. I think the early stages of development of a creative idea is a special time that should be somewhat protected, and I guess they're in it for the long haul. I'm also sympathetic to the idea that open source techbro culture isn't a panacea, and their pre-pandemic focus on in-person collaboration and continued focus on long-haul in-the-community nonprofit development is really interesting.. plus their new website will share a
lot.

text: Anyway not wanting to speak on their behalf. Clearly it doesn't belong on a list of free/open source licensed software.

elements.text: Anyway not wanting to speak on their behalf. Clearly it doesn't belong on a list of free/open source licensed software.

text:
Pondering some FoC-adjacent ideas, with the goal of finding a financially sustainable project that can fund more tentative adjacent work - <https://www.scattered-thoughts.net/writing/miscellaneous-ideas> / <https://www.scattered-thoughts.net/writing/how-to-trade-software-for-small-money/>.

Less FoC-related, I mentioned in the bottom of that post that I'd love to help someone pick up the streaming system testing work that I started in <https://www.scattered-thoughts.net/writing/internal-consistency-in-streaming-systems/>. It will be a real slog getting momentum, but there's potential to really raise the (incredibly low) bar for reliability and understand-ability in that niche.

elements.text: Pondering some FoC-adjacent ideas, with the goal of finding a financially sustainable project that can fund more tentative adjacent work -

.

Less FoC-related, I mentioned in the bottom of that post that I'd love to help someone pick up the streaming system testing work that I started in
. It will be a real slog getting momentum, but there's potential to really raise the (incredibly low) bar for reliability and understand-ability in that niche.

text:
Strong agree with <@U05SU27S1M2> that we need to experiment with new forms of collaboration. Open Source was a first step out of the industrial-capitalist mindset. We need to take more steps.

For the project list, that means thinking harder about what should and what should not be in it. Only projects from people active in our community? Only Open Source projects? I'd tone down the latter to "only projects that we can learn from", which requires less openness than Open Source.

elements.text: Strong agree with

that we need to experiment with new forms of collaboration. Open Source was a first step out of the industrial-capitalist mindset. We need to take more steps.

For the project list, that means thinking harder about what should and what should not be in it. Only projects from people active in our community? Only Open Source projects? I'd tone down the latter to "only projects that we can learn from", which requires less openness than Open Source.

text: Yes, acknowledging that the future of programming might well need to be defined outside any current community of programmers. I think <https://worrydream.com/MediaForThinkingTheUnthinkable/note.html|that's Bret Victor's position> which might be why there seems to be some animosity towards dynamicland here..

elements.text: Yes, acknowledging that the future of programming might well need to be defined outside any current community of programmers. I think
that's Bret Victor's position
which might be why there seems to be some animosity towards dynamicland here..

text:
I think the main thing wrong with Dynamicland _is_ its core, local-only, in-person philosophy! I obviously get the whole "handling real objects and interacting in person with people right next to you" idea, but to specifically cut out internet-based XR* from the discussion (and derived from that, or on top of that, having no normal internet presence and not being more open to non-in-person discussion of the ideas) seems very narrow-minded.

(* AR and VR)

elements.text: I think the main thing wrong with Dynamicland
is

its core, local-only, in-person philosophy! I obviously get the whole "handling real objects and interacting in person with people right next to you" idea, but to specifically cut out internet-based XR* from the discussion (and derived from that, or on top of that, having no normal internet presence and not being more open to non-in-person discussion of the ideas) seems very narrow-minded.

(* AR and VR)

text: It's been pretty strange mostly working in Realtalk with only myself in the room, but of course the pandemic necessitated a shift of focus on collaboration over the internet. The tables are nicely linked.

elements.text: It's been pretty strange mostly working in Realtalk with only myself in the room, but of course the pandemic necessitated a shift of focus on collaboration over the internet. The tables are nicely linked.

text: Oh, I didn't realise it uses this "internet" thing now! I didn't see anything about that. What "tables" - physical ones or database ones?

text: physical! :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Ha, right, thanks! So, is there any info anywhere online where I can read about or see this collab via linking of tables over the internet? It does sound like a significant deviation from the philosophy, and you hint that it's been happening since 2020-ish, right?

text: I feel like what's actually needed is a project wiki, not a spreadsheet, and then we can tag a project as "by a member" whenever the person working on it is active here. I keep meaning to turn <https://ivanish.ca/codex|the codex> into this...

text: I think the #1 thing that stops me is not having a good way to spin up something world-writable that has a modicum of abuse resistance.

elements.text: I think the #1 thing that stops me is not having a good way to spin up something world-writable that has a modicum of abuse resistance.

text: That's a good point. I think all my comments here are through the lens of a spreadsheet, where space is a constraint and the projects are inherently ordered. A wiki would break out of that shackle.
